title: Protocol fiction storytelling workshop

deftab720tightenfactor0

Wed, 17 Sept 25\

d
deftab720tightenfactor0

Workshop Overview: Protocol-Driven Storytelling\

ddeftab720-720tightenfactor0
• Online science fiction writing workshop led by Stanley\
• 2+ hours covering theoretical framework for crafting sci-fi stories\
• Framework based on protocol fiction - systematic approach using shared conventions between authors and readers\

d
deftab720tightenfactor0

Core Storytelling Framework\

ddeftab720-720tightenfactor0
• Authors and readers create overlapping meaning through shared protocols\

ddeftab720-1440tightenfactor0

◦
Genre conventions (sci-fi must include science/technology, world-building, what if scenarios)\

◦
Symbolic representations and metaphors\

◦
Cultural and temporal context\

ddeftab720-720tightenfactor0
• Protocol difficulty hierarchy:\

ddeftab720-1440tightenfactor0

◦
Surface elements (characters, plot) - easiest to change\

◦
Meanings - very difficult to change\

◦
Protocols themselves - hardest to change (requires collective understanding shift)\

d
deftab720tightenfactor0

Causal Layer Analysis Method\

ddeftab720-720tightenfactor0
• Four-layer narrative breakdown framework:\

ddeftab720-1440tightenfactor0

◦
Surface level - what happened\

◦
Systemic causes - why it happened (context and systems)\

◦
Worldview - beliefs, values, assumptions that informed it\

◦
Myth/metaphor - universal archetypal stories (deepest layer)\

ddeftab720-720tightenfactor0
• Example analysis using The Golden Elephant story from AI 2041 book\

ddeftab720-1440tightenfactor0

◦
Surface: AI insurance optimizing health behaviors\

◦
System: Algorithmic reinforcement of caste discrimination\

◦
Worldview: Questions about free will vs optimization\

◦
Myth: Ganesh symbol representing wisdom and obstacle removal\

d
deftab720tightenfactor0

Breakout Session Structure\

ddeftab720-720tightenfactor0
• 4 rounds in small groups (6 people each)\
• Round 1: Seed - brainstorm what if scenarios\
• Round 2: Root - explore deeper implications and changes\
• Round 3: Flower - develop specific narrative directions\
• Round 4: Fruit - finalize story concepts and genres\

d
deftab720tightenfactor0

Group Story Concepts Generated\

ddeftab720-720tightenfactor0
• Thoughts on display via neural interfaces\

ddeftab720-1440tightenfactor0

◦
Privacy implications and social protocols\

◦
Different thinking modes (visual vs verbal)\

◦
Contract and relationship changes\

ddeftab720-720tightenfactor0
• Houses as legal AI entities\

ddeftab720-1440tightenfactor0

◦
Self-setting rent based on tenant behavior\

◦
Cultural conflicts (shoes vs barefoot preferences)\

◦
Trauma and connection themes from house perspective\

ddeftab720-720tightenfactor0
• Mech vs Morph cultural war\

ddeftab720-1440tightenfactor0

◦
Mechs: technological augmentation/exoskeletons\

◦
Morphs: biological modification/genetic engineering\

◦
Romance subplot between opposing sides\

ddeftab720-720tightenfactor0
• Sea animals coordinating to exclude humans from oceans\

ddeftab720-1440tightenfactor0

◦
Climate change forcing humans back to water with gills\

◦
Succession conflict narrative (returning to ancestral home)\

d
deftab720tightenfactor0

Key Writing Principles Emphasized\

ddeftab720-720tightenfactor0
• Constraint-driven focus - return to core idea throughout crafting process\
• Intent encoding - align narrative choices with coherent worldview\
• Reflective methodology - surface hidden assumptions\
• Multi-modal thinking - consider embodiment, cultural differences, species communication\
• Genre blending for novelty\

d
deftab720tightenfactor0

Assignment\

ddeftab720-720tightenfactor0
• Write 1,000-word story using workshop concepts\
• Due September 25 (all time zones)\
• Email to Stanley with subject: COST + [title] + [name]\
• Document AI usage if applicable and reflection on co-creation process
